title: Celebrity Transformations That Will Make You Go Wow
desc: Be it for a role or simply to start living a healthier life, celebrities often undergo drastic physical transformations. Yes, we know they have expert trainers at their fingertips, but they also have determination and commitment. So, if you want to transform yourself but are feeling a tad bit uninspired, here is the much-needed motivation.

posts.title: Natalie Portman
posts.content: Natalie Portman may have won many awards for her role in the psychological drama Black Swan, but she lost around 20 lbs for that role. The dance form required her to follow a punishing routine that left her feeling like she was about to â€œdie.â€

posts.title: Adele
posts.content: Adele is a musical goddess, and her recent transformation is truly an inspiration. Post-separation from her husband in 2019, the singer, with the help of a controlled diet, has gone on to lose a whopping 100 lbs. Is this a revenge bod? Whatever it is, we 100% stan.

posts.title: Chris Hemsworth
posts.content: For his role in the 2015 survival-drama In the Heart of The Sea, the Australian actor shed around 33 pounds. However, to play Thor, he had to pack a punch. Unfortunately, getting in shape did not happen at lightning speed. Hemsworth had to train with heavyweights six days a week.

posts.title: Henry Cavill
posts.content: Henry Cavill could crush a watermelon with his bare hands, weâ€™re sure of that. The already-fit actor had to get even more ripped for his role in The Witcher , a Netflix original. In fact, he got so jacked for the role that he kept ripping his leather pants. Does anyone have this on the reel?

posts.title: Emma Stone
posts.content: For her role in the award-winning La La Land , Stone lost a considerable amount of weight but that by far is not her biggest transformation. To play the role of tennis legend Billie Jean King in Battle of the Sexes, the actress gained around 15 pounds of muscle mass to have an athletic body contrary to her usual petite figure.

posts.title: Simon Pegg
posts.content: The Shaun of the Dead star underwent a major transformation for his upcoming movie Inheritance. He went from 78kgs to 69kgs in six months and is completely ripped. Look at him, he has muscles we did not even know existed.

posts.title: Anne Hathaway
posts.content: Playing a sickly prostitute in the critically acclaimed Les Miserables, Hathaway had to chop off her hair and shed 25 pounds. However, this did not come easy. The actress stuck to a special diet to get the look of â€œnear death.â€ The deprivation of food affected her both physically and emotionally.

posts.title: Gal Gadot
posts.content: Wonderwoman is strong and lean, which meant that Gadot, although in pretty great shape, had to bulk up by a lot. Even though she may not have had any diet restrictions, her workouts were intense with no days off. She did planks and push-ups to get those crazy biceps.

posts.title: Zac Efron
posts.content: The High School Musical star went from a lean young lad to a jacked-up hottie for his role in the 2017 remake of Baywatch where he plays a lifeguard who is shirtless a lot!

posts.title: Missy Elliott
posts.content: American rapper and singer Missy Elliot flaunted her fit body back in 2014. She reportedly lost 70 pounds after committing to a healthy lifestyle after being diagnosed with Gravesâ€™ disease in 2008.

posts.title: Jonah Hill
posts.content: In an interview with Ellen, Hill revealed that as a young adult he was called â€œfat and gross and unattractive.â€ The actor has had fluctuating weight throughout his career. He first lost a tremendous amount of weight for Moneyball, which led him to be a responsible adult and lead a healthy lifestyle. Yes, you do you!

posts.title: Tom Hardy
posts.content: Over the years, this British heartthrob has played various roles, right from Venom to the villain Bane in The Dark Knight Rises. The actor follows hardcore regiments to get in shape and we are all for it!

posts.title: RenÃ©e Zellweger
posts.content: The Bridget Jonesâ€™s Diary actress had to put on 30 pounds to play Bridget in the famous rom-com franchise in 2011 and 2004. In 2002, however, she had to shed the pounds for her role in Chicago. She also lost a ton of weight for her role in the Oscar-winning movie Judy.

posts.title: Jake Gyllenhaal
posts.content: Jake Gyllenhaal had to bulk up to play a professional boxer in Southpaw. The actor revealed that he trained for six months, six hours each day to bulk up contrary to what he did for his role as a sociopathic journalist in Nightcrawler.

posts.title: Khloe Kardashian
posts.content: Khloe Kardashian was trolled for her weight when Keeping up with the Kardashians aired in 2007, but guess whoâ€™s laughing now? Following a dedicated workout schedule has helped her get physically stronger and mentally balanced.

posts.title: Snooki
posts.content: Jersey Shore reality star Snooki did not just transform her wardrobe. She took it a step further and lost around 42 lbs after the birth of her second child. In a post shared on Instagram, Snooki spoke about her struggles with her weight and how she was staying fit for her sons and herself.

posts.title: Chris Pratt
posts.content: Chris Pratt went from being the ridiculously cute Andy on Parks and Rec to a zaddy in Marvelâ€™s Guardians of the Galaxy. On IG, he captioned this picture â€œSix months no beer. #GOTG Kinda douchey to post this but my brother made me.â€ Guess we should all be thanking his brother!

posts.title: Gerard Butler
posts.content: To play the role of the King of Sparta, Butler had to get washboard abs and muscles and that was only possible with a brutal training schedule and hardcore diet. Yes, there were stunning action sequences and amazing visuals but letâ€™s also appreciate the parade of shirtless men yelling â€œThis is Sparta!â€

posts.title: Christian Bale
posts.content: Christian Bale is a method actor. For each role, he chose to lose or put on weight as the role entails. In 2004, The Machinist saw him lose a whopping 60 pounds, which bought his weight down to 120 pounds. But within five months, Bale had to put on all the weight he lost and more, as he began shooting for Batman Begins.

posts.title: Christina Aguilera
posts.content: The Dirrty singer has changed drastically ever since she debuted in 1999 and weâ€™re not just talking about her wardrobe upgrade. After giving birth to her child, the popstar lost around 40 pounds. Talk about dedication.

posts.title: Kumail Nanjiani
posts.content: After being cast in Marvelâ€™s The Eternals, the comedian showed off his stunning muscular figure in a post on Instagram. He revealed that he trained for nearly a year, ate well, had top-notch support, and lastly was committed to the task.0

posts.title: Jason Segel
posts.content: The comedian wasnâ€™t kidding when he said it wouldn't be funny when he took his shirt off, and we agree. Jason Segel had to lose weight ahead of his appearance alongside Cameron Diaz in Sex Tape.

posts.title: Hillary Swank
posts.content: In order to play the role of Maggie Fitzgerald in Million Dollar Baby, Swank bulked up. Her body was completely transformed to match that of a professional boxer. Her committed workouts and diet included almost 4 hours of training and a 4000-calorie intake.

posts.title: Ryan Reynolds
posts.content: To play the role of Hannibal King in Blade: Trinity, Reynolds gained 25 pounds and reduced his body fat to eight percent in a matter of months. Yes, months! He also transformed for his role in Deadpool. His workout routine included training for three hours a day, six days a week.

posts.title: Beyonce
posts.content: For Dreamgirls the pop icon had to lose 20 pounds in two weeks. She followed a juice cleanse, a fasting method where you can consume liquids only. Nutritionists have pointed out that the Master Cleanse diet is not healthy. Since then, the singer has gone on to promote a healthy plant-based diet along with exercise.

posts.title: Demi Moore
posts.content: Moore has revealed that she was obsessed with her body during her thirties. She went on diets and did intense workouts to look like the blockbuster diva that she is. With movies like A Few Good Men, Striptease, and Indecent Proposal, Moore showed off her body.

posts.title: Kit Harington
posts.content: The GOT star played the role of a warrior in the 2014 movie Pompeii. The actor mentioned that he has a fast metabolism, which meant putting on muscles was a task. Moreover, he had to eat around 5000 calories a day. Weâ€™re glad he took the trouble because hot damn!

posts.title: Britney Spears
posts.content: Britney Spears made a major comeback with her music and body. She got back in shape by spending time sweating at the gym and performing grueling dance routines.

posts.title: Mila Kunis
posts.content: Black Swan was taxing for Natalie portman but it was just as taxing for Kunis. The That â€˜70s Show actress also lost around 20 lbs to look petite like a ballerina.

posts.title: Jessica Simpson
posts.content: The mother of three weighed around 240 pounds after giving birth to her third child and then shed 100 pounds in a matter of six months. This seemingly impossible goal was attained by walking 14,000 steps per day and eating proper meals.

title: Classical Symphonies That Bring Peace and Tranquil
desc:
Having a hard time dealing with the chaos outside? De-stress with some beautiful, soul-soothing classical symphonies that have charmed millions of people.
 
 
 
 Social distancing and isolation can play havoc on the mind and listening to the news nowadays is more often than not nerve-wracking. Instead of listening to the same report for the fourth time, why not switch to listening to classical symphonies? Music has always played a role in binding people during harrowing times. Artists and musicians have been holding amazing live concerts online, like Lady Gagaâ€™s One World: Together at Home, to help us sail through. If youâ€™re looking for some help with falling asleep, ways to ease melancholia, or some tranquility, there is nothing better than classical symphonies.

posts.title: Moonlight Sonata by Beethoven
posts.content: Starting with a restrained first movement, a lively second movement, and a fervent third movement, this remarkable piece will definitely calm you down and alleviate your anxiety. Ludwig van Beethoven dedicated this sonata to his student Giulietta Guicciardi, a countess in her mid-teenage years.

posts.title: Sonata No. 16 in C Major by Mozart
posts.content: Mozart cataloged this symphony as for beginners and it was meant for a solo pianist. Despite its simplicity, this piece is extremely soothing and relaxing. It has a light melody that will transport you to a positive and blissful mind space.

posts.title: The Blue Danube by Johann Strauss II
posts.content: You may remember this symphony as the opening theme music in the Stanley Kubrick film 2001: A Space Odyssey. With its uplifting melody, the instrumental version of this harmonious waltz by Johann Strauss II is absolutely therapeutic for an over-stressed soul.

posts.title: Air on the G String by JS Bach
posts.content: A stunning symphony, Bachâ€™s Air on the G String will truly get you floating on clouds. Originally written for his patron Prince Leopold of Anhalt, it can be played on solo violin or strings and keyboard and is a soulful, awe-inspiring arrangement.

posts.title: Raindrops by Chopin
posts.content: Do you know the sound of falling raindrops is akin to white noise? It calms the mind. The ambient sound of raindrops falling can really help you sleep and the resounding chords quavering in Frederic Chopinâ€™s masterpiece captures its essence beautifully.

posts.title: Trois Gymnopedies by Erik Satie
posts.content: Trois Gymnopedies is a symphony with three solo piano pieces composed by Erik Satie and it is wonderfully mild. The lilting melodies may sound a bit melancholic, yet the overall feeling is that of relaxation and the gentle afternoon breeze.

posts.title: Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun by Debussy
posts.content: Claude Debussyâ€™s The Prelude to the Afternoon is a brilliant orchestral symphonic poem that he finished composing in 1894. It is a spell-binding symphony of 10 wonderful minutes and takes inspiration from the French poet StÃ©phane MallarmÃ©â€™s 1876 creation, â€œLâ€™AprÃ©s-midi dâ€™un Faune.â€

posts.title: Symphony No. 2 by Brahms
posts.content: Symphony No. 2 in D major by Johannes Brahms has been often called his â€œPastoral,â€ referencing one of Beethovenâ€™s greatest works. When you listen to this symphony, you will instantly feel a rush of warmth and serenity from the combination of tuba, trombones, and timpani.

posts.title: Symphony No. 3 by Mahler
posts.content: Gustav Mahler encapsulated a wide variety of beliefs in his Symphony No. 3. Mahler ardently loved nature and this classical piece reflects that wonderfully. Listening to it will make you feel more attuned to nature, even when you are staying in.

posts.title: Symphony No. 3 by Beethoven
posts.content: Known as one of the greatest symphonies ever composed, Beethovenâ€™s Symphony No. 3 is truly a delight to listen to. Called Eroica, this lively compositionâ€™s name has quite a story behind it. However, you really donâ€™t need to know that to experience its wondrous qualities.

posts.title: Water Music by Handel
posts.content: A pleasant orchestral arrangement, Water Music by George Frideric Handel was originally composed for a concert on the River Thames, requested by King George I. The jovial string melody will help you breathe easy and will transport you to a calm place mentally.

posts.title: Canon in D The Elegance of Pachelbel
posts.content: If you are looking for some positive vibes to start your day, listen to Pachelbelâ€™s Canon in D The Elegance. A famous classical piece, this symphony comprises of melodious violin arrangements and tight harmonies. The repetitive melodies in this symphony are meditative, leaving you entranced.

posts.title: Symphony No. 5 in E flat major, Op 82 by Sibelius
posts.content: Symphony No. 5 in E flat major, Op 82 is known to be one of the best symphonies of Jean Sibelius. The gorgeous movements begin as a bright sunny morning on a cold winter day. Listen to this symphony for its rich melodic development.

posts.title: Symphony No. 2 in E minor, Op 27 by Rachmaninoff
posts.content: Sergei Rachmaninoffâ€™s Symphony No. 2 in E minor is known to be one of the most powerful symphonies in music history. The 2014 Alejandro GonzÃ¡lez IÅ„Ã¡rritu film Birdman has the strong melodies in the symphonyâ€™s second movement as the background score in several scenes.

posts.title: Symphony No. 6 in B minor by Tchaikovsky
posts.content: Symphony No. 6 in B minor was Pyotr Ilych Tchaikovskyâ€™s final symphony. When you listen to this catharsis-inducing classical piece, do not be misled by the somber beginning. For soon enough, the harmonies emerge and envelop you in a soothing mist of beautiful music.

title: Constructive Courses to Explore While in Self-quarantine
desc:
With social gatherings and holidays canceled, schools and offices closed, and commercial establishments shut, there is nothing much to do but sit around and wait for the COVID-19 outbreak to die down. While working from home and home chores can keep you busy, boredom is common. Hmmm, how does learning a new skill sound? No, we are not talking about fat textbooks and a lot of reading; just something that requires a few hours every week and a little determination. You guessed it right, online courses.
 
 To get you started, we have listed 18 courses that we reckon you will enjoy. From time management to guitar lessons for beginners, hereâ€™s the best material from the worldâ€™s most respected universities and institutions to keep you busy.

posts.title: Dog Emotion and Cognition (Duke University)
posts.content: If the only silver lining about being in quarantine is spending more time with your pooch, weâ€™d recommend this for you. Taught by Brian Hare (Associate Professor â€“ Evolutionary Anthropology), this 8-week long course explains dog psychology in detail and covers recent discoveries of their thoughts and feelings about us. You can use this course as a medium to strengthen your bond with your furry best friend.

posts.title: Finance for Everyone: Smart Tools for Decision-Making (University of Michigan)
posts.content: The sudden blow that coronavirus caused to the economy has landed us in financial worries, compelling many of us to rethink our spending habits. Off lately, if you are contemplating the same, you should take this finance course by Gautam Kaul of The University of Michigan to gain fundamental knowledge and skills to help you make practical monetary decisions in life.

posts.title: Know Thyself - The Value and Limits of Self-Knowledge: The Examined Life (The University of Edinburgh)
posts.content: While in isolation, quite a few of us will end up introspecting. If thatâ€™s the case with you, this course will help you know yourself. This 4 week-long course will get you acquainted with major themes from Western, Buddhist, and classical Chinese approaches to self-knowledge. Likewise, the coursework will cover contemporary research in experimental social psychology, neuroscience that influences emotions, philosophy, decision making, and self-image.

posts.title: Work Smarter, Not Harder: Time Management for Personal & Professional Productivity (University of California)
posts.content: Instructor Margaret Meloni will teach you how to get organized by achieving deeper personal and professional awareness. Plus, youâ€™ll be guided to use tools and techniques that will enable you to set goals, schedule, prioritize, and delegate for better time management and to boost productivity. This is a terrific course if you cannot stick to an agenda, want to overcome tardiness, or just have a lot on your plate.

posts.title: Learning How to Learn: Powerful mental tools to help you master tough subject (McMaster University, University of California San Diego)
posts.content: At some point, we have all struggled with learning a new subject. Thatâ€™s why we suggest this online course that introduces you to instrumental learning methods used by experts in art, music, math, literature, science, and many other disciplines. Whether a high schooler, college student, or a full-time professional, this course will help you tackle everything that has been holding you back, from learning illusions to procrastination.

posts.title: Happier Employees and Return-On-Investment Course (University of Texas)
posts.content: Career is an integral part of your life, but feeling discontented with work could affect productivity, and, ultimately, your personal life. Staying at home further magnifies this feeling, but this course can help you determine the importance of happiness at work and ways to enhance it. Whether youâ€™re an employee, team leader, manager, or business owner, it can help you create a more positive working environment.

posts.title: Inspiring Leadership through Emotional Intelligence (Case Western Reserve University)
posts.content: This course by Professor Richard Boyatzis is a must if you have recently embraced a leadership position. It will allow you to build lasting professional relationships and drive your team to their maximum potential by refining key attributes like emotional intelligence, mindfulness, and compassion. Through this course, youâ€™ll also get an insight into the neuroscience behind â€œresonant and dissonant leadershipâ€ and its effects.

posts.title: Everyday Parenting: The ABCs of Child Rearing (Yale University)
posts.content: Parenting is no cakewalk, and it can get more difficult to keep up when the tots have no school, homework, and play dates during quarantine. With Everyday Parenting, you gain access to a toolkit of behavior-changing techniques that can make the days easier. These will improve your approach with both children and adolescents, and the course also debunks common parenting misconceptions and points out ineffective strategies that parents usually use.

posts.title: Creativity & Entrepreneurship (Berklee)
posts.content: This course aims to motivate you to explore your inner creativity that can be honed for advancing your career or developing a business. It features interviews with distinguished innovators, visual artists, educators, and chefs delving deeper into their creative and entrepreneurial journey. With this course, you can unlock your personal creative process and develop the knowledge, basic mindset, and insight that are indispensable in chasing your entrepreneurial exploits.

posts.title: Think Again I: How to Understand Arguments (Duke University)
posts.content: Want to try something challenging? Give this course by Dr. Walter Sinnott-Armstrong and Dr. Ram Neta a shot. They will train you to adopt some simple but crucial rules in thinking and explain some tempting mistakes to elude while reasoning. You will learn to identify and assess arguments through examples of politicians, teachers, and salesmen, guiding you to construct arguments to solidify your belief system and make decisions.

posts.title: The Modern World, Part One: Global History from 1760 to 1910 (University of Virginia)
posts.content: Intrigued by history but never had the time to explore it? With free time during quarantine, grab the opportunity and enroll for this course by Philip Zelikow that examines modern history from â€œa global perspective.â€ In Part One, you will get an understanding of the befalling of key historic events like the Commercial, Military, and Democratic Revolutions, along with the ensuing wars and the transformation of the world.

posts.title: Modern Art & Ideas (MoMA)
posts.content: If art is where your heart is, you should check out this 5-week long course on modern art. Through this course, you will be able to grasp how artists take inspiration from their environment and create art as a medium to express and question identity. Likewise, youâ€™ll explore how everyday objects are used to defy assumptions, along with the significance of cultural, social, and political themes used in art.

posts.title: Introduction to Typography (California Institute of the Arts)
posts.content: If you are an aspiring graphic designer and are particularly interested in typography, this course by Cal Arts is ideal for you. Youâ€™ll be taught the cultural and aesthetic history of typefaces and the major pragmatic concerns that need to be considered while selecting and combining typefaces. After the course, youâ€™ll also get an opportunity to showcase your skills by designing a full-scale typographic poster.

posts.title: Modern & Contemporary American Poetry â€“ ModPo (University of Pennsylvania)
posts.content: ModPo is an introductory course to modern and contemporary American poetry that emphasizes experimental verse, from the work of Emily Dickinson and Walt Whitman to more recent poetry. During this 10-week course, you will be taught about poetry with the help of video and community discussions. What sets this course apart is that there are live webcasts arranged on a weekly basis.

posts.title: Engineering Health: Introduction to Yoga and Physiology (New York University Tandon School of Engineering)
posts.content: Interested in health? Take this 6-week course that focuses on the therapeutic effects of yoga and meditation on chronic conditions like hypertension, insomnia, diabetes, stress, and PTSD. Typically, this course is targeted toward yoga practitioners and teachers, but youâ€™re welcome to join if you are curious about the physiological benefits of yoga. Given the stress during quarantine, we think this course could be valuable in mitigating the anxiety.

posts.title: Our Earth's Future (American Museum of Natural History)
posts.content: This course offers an introductory syllabus that explains climate change from scratch. In this course, you will learn from the experts of various disciplines how climate change is impacting populations, how we are inducing it, and the combined effects on the future of Earth. By the end of the course, you will be able to understand critical scientific principles, deal with misconceptions, and share your knowledge on the topic.

posts.title: Guitar for Beginners (Berklee)
posts.content: Now that you donâ€™t have the excuse of not having enough time, pick up your guitar thatâ€™s gathering dust in the corner and enroll for this awesome beginnerâ€™s course led by Thaddeus Hogarth. It covers the essentials of playing acoustic and electric guitar. From familiarizing yourself to the anatomy of a guitar to playing some mellifluous tunes easily, this course could well be the start of your musical journey.

posts.title: Stanford Introduction to Food and Health (Stanford University)
posts.content: This course addresses the growing trend of lifestyle diseases due to unhealthy diets. It takes a practical approach to explain the effects of nutrition, instead of the complex ways that donâ€™t offer much of a comprehensive solution. The course provides a background on food and nutrients, contemporary eating trends, sustainable solutions that can help you pick healthy more often, and grocery shopping tips, and also includes a cooking workshop.

title: DC Movies Get New Release Dates and the Internet Cant Keep Calm
desc: It is no surprise that DC-verse releases have been delayed. It is also no surprise, that the fans stormed social media with their enlivened thoughts and opinions. You were hyped to witness the new The Batman on the silver screen or find out how Steve Trevor returns from the dead. But then, Shazam! And everything got pushed to the future in a Flash. See what we did there? The announcement for the indefinite postponing of all movies witnessed DC universe fans at their opinionated best, whether they had theories to share, ideas to discuss, or hope to spread. In fact, even costuming got a few tweets dedicated to it. Take a look at what they had to say on Twitter and maybe add your own take too!

posts.content:

title: DIY Home Decor Ideas to Keep You Occupied During Quarantine
desc: The lockdown is officially under effect and staying indoors under quarantine can be tough. One of the key challenges rests with managing all the free time you have, even after working from home. Plus, there is only so much television you can watch or games you can play before you get bored of being indoors all day. So, to help you manage the boredom and at the same time give your beautiful home an inexpensive makeover, we have scoured the Internet to find interesting DIY build projects. The possibilities are limitless with these creative ideas so take a look.

posts.title: Find your space
posts.content: Sheldon Cooper isnâ€™t the only one who likes his spot! Since you?ll be spending most of your day working, we suggest you find your spot and claim the space. This will also largely depend on whether you stay alone or have a roommate, or live in a house with a spare room that can be turned into your temp workspace. Once you narrow down where you want to work, we can explore the how of things.

posts.title: Staying online
posts.content: There is simply no point in setting up your workstation where the Internet connectivity is compromised. You might even want to consider moving the wireless router to where you set up to ensure maximum range and bandwidth. So change your layout accordingly before you get comfy. Remember to connect everything to a portable power backup so you don?t have to worry in case the power goes out.

posts.title: Build a sit or stand workstation
posts.content: Using nothing but some wood planks and spare shelf brackets lying around in the garage, you can build yourself a sit or stand workstation. Simply adjust the height of the desk according to your convenience and viola, youâ€™ve got yourself a decent and inexpensive piece of furniture made right at home. So, when the mood strikes, get the rest of your work done standing.

posts.title: Proper lighting is key
posts.content: When you are working indoors, ensure the room gets plenty of sunlight. Or at the very least, the indoor lighting should be sufficient enough to reduce the need for backlight from the screen. You can buy and install small table lights or consider increasing the wattage of existing light bulbs. Remember your productivity automatically increases in the right workspace.

posts.title: Room curtains for dividing space
posts.content: Have a few spare curtains lying around? Use them as space dividers to ensure some privacy. While they are not necessarily soundproof, these DIY curtain partitions can isolate you in your workstation and let others know you mean business. This is a great way to mark your space especially if you are sharing the room with one or more of your siblings.

posts.title: Upholster furniture
posts.content: When you are not using your chair, how about swapping up and upholstering the cushions? You?ll be surprised to know that it takes very little fabric (you can even use scrap sheets or curtains) and materials for this DIY project. Simply check out free videos on YouTube that come with step by step instructions and spend some time sprucing up your workspace.

posts.title: Floating desks
posts.content: These desks are a true space saver and can be installed in any room. You donâ€™t even need a lot of material as a couple of sturdy wood planks, screws, braces and brackets with your basic tool kit will work fine. These desks can be reshaped and remodeled to fit just about anywhere you like. You can also build an additional layer to store all your office essentials.

posts.title: Compact wall storage
posts.content: Often you might notice a corner or part of the wall that is deeper in comparison to the rest of the space. It may look like a design flaw but this is the perfect space to build a custom storage unit. Here again, using the bare minimum of materials, you can install DIY shelves. You can find online resources with step by step instructions to build a wall storage unit today.

posts.title: Upholster the closet doors
posts.content: All you need is a staple gun, and a piece of cloth and you are all set to give your bedroom closet a makeover. Simply measure the surface area and cut the fabric accordingly to make the door covers. Then staple them in place with minimum effort. Using this technique, you can also cover up appliances to give your living room or kitchen a unique aesthetic look.

posts.title: Folding desk
posts.content: A space saver, you can just pack this folding desk and move everything to another room without much hassle. Folding desks can be built using a few good wood planks, sturdy hinges to support the movable legs, and to finish it all up add a nice coat of varnish. With folding desks, just move around the house when you get bored of sitting in one place.

posts.title: A fresh look walls
posts.content: A home or room makeover doesnâ€™t necessarily have to be extravagant. Changing the wallpaper or adding a fresh coat of paint that contrasts well with the furniture can be your next DIY project to pass time. Surely youâ€™ll have a few options and a couple of cans of paint lying around in storage. So, why not make the most of the extra time and redo the walls.

posts.title: Keep some plants indoors
posts.content: Move some of those small plants indoors to spruce up the living room. Alternatively, there are several DIY wall garden ideas that you can explore to create your own indoor garden. For example, you can make an herb garden from scratch right in the kitchen with just a few seed packets and some compact container beds (could be anything from unused jars and small clay pots to compact plastic trays).

posts.title: Make the most of vertical space
posts.content: Most of us donâ€™t realize the vertical space potential in our homes. Building up is the new way to go and with the quarantine in effect, why not use this time to build a wall pegboard. Using just a few giant sheets of plywood and some handy wooden dowels, you can construct your very own multipurpose pegboard wall.

posts.title: Label and reorganize
posts.content: When was the last time you looked into the walk-in closet, the attic, or even behind the garage? You just might find an old chair or small desk that can be a great addition to your DIY workspace. It's also a great way to ensure everything is in the right place and you can spend your own sweet time to manage the boredom of WFH.

posts.title: Invisible bookcase
posts.content: Most of the space under a floating or corner desk goes unused. You can simply design and install a bookcase leaving some room for your legs. This way, all the material you?ll need for reference is right there with easy access. Also, during the day when you feel like taking a break from work, pick up one of your favorite books or comics from right under and enjoy.

posts.title: Entertainment unit
posts.content: Self-contained entertainment units are easy to build and install, with minimum labor and effort. The best part is, you can set up your television, home speaker system, and your gaming console all in one place. You will be able to utilize your space better with a multipurpose unit.

posts.title: Rearrange everything
posts.content: One of the best DIY projects under lockdown can simply involve you rearranging all the furniture, and we mean all of it. You might just figure out a more productive and accessible layout by shuffling everything around the room. In the process, you?ll also end up identifying the ones that are least useful so those can be replaced to make more space.

posts.title: Hang up some art
posts.content: If you think those walls look mighty plain, why not liven it up with some art? In fact, itâ€™s the perfect spot to hang up a painting or piece of craft that your children have made. So, get your children to do some DIY arts and crafts to keep them occupied as well during the lockdown. This way, they wonâ€™t disturb you while you are busy working.

posts.title: Make desk accessories
posts.content: Charging wires and accessories are a real pain, especially when it comes to managing the free ends. No matter how hard you try, one or two will be dangling off your desk or might get stuck under the legs of the chair. This simple hack of using big binder clips to organize your laptop, phone and other peripheral charging wires can save you much of the hassle during WFH phase.

title: Dua Lipa's 'Future Nostalgia' Making Our Quarantine Time Fly
desc:
Music has always been a saving grace and this time itâ€™s no different. Dua Lipaâ€™s new album Future Nostalgia is saving the world one pop song at a time. 
 
 2020 has been a rollercoaster with all the unexpected twists and turns. The world is stuck in their homes and we are all losing our minds a little more with each passing day. With social distancing in action, even celebrities are trying to find something to do. In the midst of all these dark clouds, Future Nostalgia turned out to be a silver lining. title: Fabulous Singers You Probably Didn't Know Belonged to the LGBTQ+ Community
desc: Present day society has come a long way from the times of the Stonewall uprising. Identity is now a fluid concept and more and more people are normalizing the concept of there being no norm. A lot of this change came not only from the activism of common folk who refused to let discussions die but also from celebrities who identified with the community and fought to make themselves heard on public forums. Itâ€™s 2020 now, and even though the LGBTQ+ community faces much lesser stigma, a lot of us struggle with coming to terms with our identities. So, hereâ€™s a list of all the singers who belong to the rainbow community to motivate you to live your own truth, just as they are living their own.

posts.title: This up and coming rapper who literally changed the country game
posts.content: On the last day of Pride Month in 2019, Lil Nas X released the album art for his EP â€œ7â€. The cover had the rapper wearing a cowboy hat and riding a horse on an â€œold town roadâ€ with rainbow lights in the background. Once fans began commenting on and questioning the symbolism, the singer-rapper said he thought everyone already knew that he belonged to the LGBTQ+ community. Chill guy extraordinaire and a hoot on Twitter, whatâ€™s not to love?

posts.title: And this singer whoâ€™s sorry, not sorry about being genderfluid
posts.content: In a 2017 Youtube documentary, Lovato revealed that her love is not barred by constraints of gender. Since coming out she has mentioned that she loves the freedom that comes with her fluidity. Not forgetting to mention, she now can flirt with whoever she wants! A brilliant perspective, that one right there.

posts.title: This timeless singer whose vocals stunned millions
posts.content: Amy Winehouse used her music to touch the souls of millions even as she struggled with various addictions, leading to her untimely demise. There were always rumors regarding her sexuality and she never did anything to squash those. Years after her passing, singer Neon Hitch claimed they had a specific memory together and that Amy had introduced her to being a lesbian. The troubled musician had once said she would like her dream superpower to be having super sexuality.

posts.title: Not to mention, this icon who broke stereotypes before it was a thingâ„¢
posts.content: David Bowie is undoubtedly an international icon and will be one forever. But, aside from oodles of talent, what makes him even more memorable was how he owned his identity. Back when coming out as a homosexual was stigmatized and frowned on, David came out as gay in a 1972 issue of Englandâ€™s Melody Maker and the lyricism in his music was never seen the same way again.

posts.title: Pop culture adores this singer who has bloomed outside and within the LGBTQ+ community
posts.content: In 2013, back when Troye Sivan was a budding YouTuber, he came out as part of the LBGTQ+ community with a video titled â€œComing Out.â€ Since then, heâ€™s gone on to become a major pop +star with a successful career in the music industry and ensures to include representation in his lyrics and music videos. The upper echelons have so much to learn from him dear audience, so much to learn!

posts.title: Also also, this singer who was and will be a Queen until the end of time
posts.content: Even though Queen frontman Freddie Mercury never did a formal coming out interview, he was openly in a relationship with Jim Hutton from 1985 until his unfortunate demise. Throughout his career, he faced rumors about his sexuality, most of which originated from his extravagant style, flamboyant and groundbreaking outfits that tore down societal norms and ridiculously ahead-of-its-time music. He wanted to break free and so he did!

posts.title: This singer who wants to swing, albeit from a chandelier
posts.content: Identifying herself as queer in 2013, Sia has always been open about her identity, mental health issues and more. To dedicate herself to the queer community in a more meaningful way, she wrote a brief letter for Billboardâ€™s â€œLove Letter to the LGBTQ Communityâ€ in 2017 where she mentioned the struggles within the community. This vocal queen may hide behind oversized wigs but makes sure her voice is heard where it counts!

posts.title: Plus, this vocalist who was one of the harmonies from Fifth Harmony
posts.content: Ex-member of British girl-band Fifth Harmony, Lauren Jauregui came out in 2016 in an open letter to Trump supporters. She then went on to star alongside Halsey in music videos portraying same-sex love while advocating for LGBTQ+ rights. In a candid interview with Billboard, the pop star spoke about her bisexuality and falling in love with peopleâ€™s souls. Talk about a Bo$$!!

posts.title: And this star whoâ€™s all about that m.i.l.f money
posts.content: In a 2009 interview with the Advocate, Fergie confirmed that sheâ€™s bisexual and also commented that she finds women beautiful (but then who doesnâ€™t, hello?) and that she is not ashamed of her sexuality. Like a breath of fresh air, the ex-Black Eyed Peas member had never shied away from her sexuality. She is and will always be Fergalicious!

posts.title: This vocalist who is also a model, actor, writer and a proud member of the LGBTQ+ community
posts.content: Cara Delvigne has never been shy about her sexuality but when a Vogue writer suggested to the top model that bisexuality is a phase, she addressed it with a simple yet savage comment that went something like this â€” â€œMy sexuality is not a phase.â€ She later told The New York Times, â€œI am who I am.â€

posts.title: Remember this German pop star who embraced her trans identity at the age of 12?
posts.content: Kim Petras began hormone therapy at the age of twelve as she began her transitioning. Since then, she has attained fame for her unique pop music but rather than choosing to gloss over difficult times, she has used her fame to discuss her identity. She has even gone on record to speak about â€œfeeling suicidalâ€ when she was in the wrong body.

posts.title: How could we forget this singer that legit makes us Panic! At the Disco?
posts.content: Panic! At the Disco frontman, Brendon Urie is amazingly talented and even though heâ€™s married to a woman, heâ€™s gone on record to mention that heâ€™s not opposed to being with a man. He identifies as pansexual and has since literally forever been breaking down masculine stereotypes and playing around with themes of sexuality through his music. The only panic he causes is in a regressive society!

posts.title: It would be a crime to forget the OG Tik Tok girl
posts.content: The pop goddess Kesha admitted to being a member of the LGBTQ+ community in an interview with Seventeen Magazine in 2013. She spoke about how she loves people and that itâ€™s not about the gender of a person. Along with gifting us with an openness rarely seen in celebrities, letâ€™s not forget that she gave us some absolute bangers that will be played for generations to come.

posts.title: This singer who is one of the most celebrated pop artists of recent times
posts.content: Hayley Kiyoko aka Lesbian Jesus, as dubbed by fans, has always shared her experiences through her singing. Her music videos vastly feature same-sex love stories and have these moody tones nobody can get enough of. Her only hope is that people watch this and learn to be not scared of accepting themselves.

posts.title: This singer who will give you feels you didnâ€™t know could exist
posts.content: Frank Ocean celebrates his sexuality and relationships with men through his music. In fact, before he released his debut album â€œChannel Orangeâ€, he shared a very intimate note on Tumblr, which mentioned the inspiration behind his music, his first love, and how he felt like a free man. Okay, going to listen to the album and cry in the bathroom at work, brb!

posts.title: This singer who we all lovingly know as Rocketman
posts.content: Elton Johnâ€™s fiery outfits, vibrant music, and larger-than-life persona made him a fan favorite for generations to come. Apart from being celebrated for his eccentricities, he is also celebrated for being very open about his sexuality in a time when it was not very accepted in society. In his usual open manner, he shared his thoughts about how everyone is bisexual to a certain extent and later identified himself as gay.

posts.title: But, it ainâ€™t no lie, this singer is not bi-bi-bi
posts.content: Member of the 1990â€™s boyband NSYNC, Lance Bass came out as gay in a cover story for People magazine in 2006. Speaking about how he never acted on or mentioned his sexuality before, he told People that he was afraid his sexuality would end up overpowering everything else in his career. The pop star married actor Michael Turchin in 2014 and is loving the life they both share. A happy ending if we ever saw one!

posts.title: This singer who just canâ€™t be stopped (even with a wrecking ball)
posts.content: Miley Cyrus has come a long way from being Disneyâ€™s Hannah Montana. In 2015, she mentioned sheâ€™s very open about her sexuality and that she identified as pansexual in a frank interview with Time Magazine. She also considers herself as genderfluid as she hates being put in a box. Lots of sides to this coin, unlike what you believed in childhood!

posts.title: This singer who identifies herself as pansexual
posts.content: Janelle Monae is a superior songstress, thereâ€™s no denying that but, what you probably did not know is that she is also an LGBTQ+ icon. Identifying as bisexual and pansexual, Monae is very outspoken about her sexuality, gender fluidity, and her intentions to be open to learning more. As of now, she is rumored to be dating actress Tessa Thompson. We need more tea on this relationship!!!

posts.title: This singer who likes her girls just like she likes her honey
posts.content: A long-time visible member of the LGBTQ+ community, Kehlani has clarified that sheâ€™s queer, not bi or straight. She also mentioned that sheâ€™s been making music about women her entire career but once she wrote Honey and used the right pronouns, she realized that people needed that representation and how much it inspired them to share their own experiences and be bolder in everyday life. We love ourselves women unafraid to speak their minds!

posts.title: This fabulous queen who has been ruling hearts and screens since 1993
posts.content: RuPaulâ€™s album Supermodel of the World was a phenomenal success and if you havenâ€™t heard it, you need to sashay away. He is one of the most famous drag queens in the U.S and has been serving lewks from day 1 in front of the camera. Post his musical success he landed a talk-show on VH1 which always tackled topics such as black empowerment, misogyny, and female empowerment.

posts.title: This singer who finds labels tricky AF
posts.content: Rachel Wood has gone on record to say she prefers the identity queer. She used to previously identify as bisexual and spoke about how bisexuality doesnâ€™t mean halfway gay and straight but rather itâ€™s own identity and later mentioned that she finds labels tricky. Can we get a yaass?

posts.title: This â€˜The Hunger Gamesâ€™ actress who identifies as gender non-binary and pansexual
posts.content: Amanda Stenberg told Seventeen Magazine that gender and sexuality are fluid and that theyâ€™re glad that people from the LGBTQ+ community can identify themselves using the umbrella term â€œqueerâ€ because so many labels exist under it. We could not be more appreciative of these powerhouses refusing to let themselves be put into a box.

posts.title: This singer who is too good at goodbyes
posts.content: As of September 2019, singer Sam Smith came out as gender fluid and began using the â€œthey/themâ€ pronouns on a social media post. They have always been proud of who they are and have also been an active voice for LGBTQ+ rights. How many reasons can one person give for us to be in love with them? Weâ€™re still counting...

posts.title: And, this singer who came out of the closet on his official website
posts.content: In 2010, Livinâ€™ La Vida Loca singer Ricky Martin came out of the closet by posting a lengthy note on his official website. He wrote - â€œI am proud to say that I am a fortunate homosexual manâ€ after many years of rumors surrounding his sexual orientation. More power to you sir.

posts.title: This celebrity who is clearly an ICON
posts.content: Jaden Smith has always broken social gender norms with his unique gender-fluid styles. After he received all the backlash for being himself, he stated that if he wanted to wear a dress, he would. And thatâ€™s on periodt! He even co-owns a gender-neutral clothing line called MSFTS.

posts.title: This unstoppable singer has established himself as a bright queer artist
posts.content: In the music video for his debut track Marrow, Vincint featured people from different ethnic backgrounds and from the LGBTQ+ community. Heâ€™s been very outspoken about his identity as a black gay man and always emphasizes the universal message of love. It is themes and messages such as this one that makes music so much more relatable!

posts.title: And this singer whoâ€™s no more walking down a lonely road
posts.content: Open to speaking about the punk-rock scene or his sexuality, Greenday frontman Billie Jean Armstrong told The Advocate that he identifies as bisexual in an interview with them in 1995. In fact, he thinks people are born bisexual but society tells us itâ€™s bad. A year before this, in 1994, he got married to his now-wife Adrienne and even had his first son soon after.

posts.title: And lastly, our Ra-Ra queen
posts.content: In 2009, Lady Gaga mentioned that sheâ€™s had sexual relationships with women in a TV interview with Barbara Walters. She later rebuffed rumors that she came out as bisexual for marketing, stating that this is who she is and who she has always been. Unapologetically herself, this vocal powerhouse has never shied away from talking about things that mattered.

posts.title: This musical star who sings about hating everybody but has always loved and owned her identity
posts.content: Halsey, who rose to fame by sharing her music on social media platforms has always been very vocal about her sexuality. Coming out as bisexual since she blew up in 2015, she has openly talked about the challenges and misconceptions associated with the term bisexual, which is NOT a phase. From adding female pronouns to her lyrics to giving powerful speeches at pride parades, Halsey is truly an iconic figure in the community and we stan!Â

title: Got Leftovers? Whip up Delish Meals with These Ideas
desc:
Have leftovers and donâ€™t know what to do with them? Your leftovers donâ€™t need to be thrown. Check out these recipes to turn your leftovers into meals!
 
 
 
 
 
 Did you ever buy too much cheese (if thatâ€™s even a thing) and are worried about it going bad? Did you make too much mashed potato last night and donâ€™t know what to do with it? Hold on. Your extra food and leftovers have a ton of possibilities than just landing up in the garbage bin. Your extra cheese can be transformed into a French entrÃ©e, Fromage Fort. Donâ€™t believe us? Check out some awesome recipes to make the best of your leftovers. Say ciao to wasting food!

posts.title: Fatteh
posts.content:
View this post on Instagram

Fatteh is the perfect lockdown food. Originating during WW1 in the Levant, it was a way of using whatever leftovers people had in the house when fresh food was hard to come by. It is a layered dish with bits of cut bread at the bottom covered with a stewed vegetable or meat and topped with a garlicky yoghurt tahini sauce. To elevate it a notch further, finish off with sizzling butter or ghee fried nuts, some chopped fresh parsley and of course some pomegranate seeds! If you want to find out more join us this Friday at 3pm london time for a live how to. ????????â€????* * * * * #catering #cateringservice #hongkong #myhkmoment #pomegranatekitchen #cooking #cookingathome #cheflife #buzzfeast #londoncaterer #londoncatering #londoneventplanner #hongkongfoodie #londonfoodies #healthyfood #fatteh #levant #syrianfood #lebanesefood #lockdownfood #leftoversforlunch #chickpeas #tahini #pittabread #brunchathome

A post shared by Pomegranate Kitchen (@pomkitch) on May 6, 2020 at 4:16am PDT

With some bread, leftover stewed veggies or meat, tahini sauce, and yogurt you can make this super-easy and filling dish. During WWI, when food was difficult to buy, people got creative and created fatteh. Find this recipe by @pomkitch.

posts.title: Spiced chickpeas salad
posts.content:
View this post on Instagram

Spiced chickpeas, spinach, avocado, juicy cherry tomatoes and lemon tahini dressing. After all the sunshine of the past few weeks I think the rain is quite welcoming. Certainly good for the seedlings in the vegetable patch. Itâ€™s amazing how everything looks so much greener now. We made falafel on Saturday. I saved some cooked chickpeas to either make humus with or pop into a salad. Well salad took my fancy today. I popped the cooked chickpeas in a pan with a little olive oil, cumin and cayenne to warm through and absorb the spices and then add a little sprinkling of white wine vinegar. I always have spinach in my fridge, I really like it as a salad leaf, add tomatoes and avocado and a tahini dressing. Put a tablespoon of tahini in a bowl and add the juice of half a lemon and stir. It will thicken significantly so add a tablespoon of boiling water and stir to a thin pouring consistency. Season and drizzle over the salad.

A post shared by ???? Nordic Kitchen stories ???? (@nordickitchenstories) on Apr 28, 2020 at 4:21am PDT

Make something healthy and fun with your leftover chickpeas rather than using it for a regular hummus. Check out @nordickkitchenstoriesâ€™s absolutely fantastic take on spiced chickpeas with some veggies. Who knew leftovers could make for a healthy meal!

title: Great Ways to Stay Fit Without a Gym
desc: As the days merge into each other and our schedules and routines go out the window, trying to stay on track can get difficult. Just because we cannot leave our homes, does not mean we do not have to stay on the couch. So, if youâ€™ve been thinking about working out but donâ€™t know where to start, youâ€™ve come to the right place. Here is a compilation of 15 easy exercises and hobbies that will keep you busy and fit.

posts.title: Meditation - To keep you sane while youâ€™re indoors
posts.content: One of the easiest exercises to do indoors is meditation. Not only will this help reduce your anxiety during this trying time, itâ€™s a great way to train your mind to be attentive, aware and alert. While this isnâ€™t a traditional exercise and it wonâ€™t help you burn body fat, itâ€™ll definitely help you achieve emotional stability and help you get ready to tackle the other exercises on this list.

posts.title: Skipping - If you donâ€™t want to walk, try skipping
posts.content: Did you know that skipping for ten minutes is the same as running a mile in eight minutes? It works out your abdominal muscles to stabilize the rest of your body and improves your coordination and stamina. So, start with a plan. You can choose to measure your skipping by the number of skips or total time spent skipping. What are you waiting for? Go on!

posts.title: Burpees - What even are these things?
posts.content: Burpees are living hell but they are also one of the most effective and intense aerobic exercises out there. As a matter of fact, research shows that it burns up to 50% more fat than any other exercise and helps improve your metabolism as it continues burning fat throughout the day. Start with a basic 4-step burpee and work your way to a stronger body!

posts.title: Jumping lunges - Lunges with a little twist!
posts.content: Burpees are good, but if youâ€™re finding them too challenging, you can try jumping lunges. Lunges with a little twist! These are great in building stamina and developing your cardiovascular system, so you could add them to your cardio workout especially if youâ€™ve missed leg day. This exercise will do wonders when it comes to your quadriceps, theyâ€™ll be faster and stronger before you know it.

posts.title: Shadow boxing - Where you wonâ€™t get hurt
posts.content: A great thing about cardio is that it comes in many forms - you have walking, running, skipping and even shadow boxing. This exercise keeps you on your toes (literally) and will help you build your cardiovascular strength and endurance, legs, arms, and even your core. You can either do high intensity or low-intensity shadow boxing as per your convenience.

posts.title: Press-ups/Push-ups - Get those shoulder muscles popping
posts.content: Push-ups are another exercise that can be done at home with no equipment, all you need is the willpower to do it. It helps build your shoulder muscles and strengthens your shoulder joints by using multiple muscle groups. They can be a bit difficult in the beginning but if youâ€™re accustomed to doing push-ups you can challenge yourself to harder kinds of push-ups.

posts.title: Squats - Tone those leg muscles with a simple move
posts.content: One of the best-known exercises to build your leg muscles and glutes are squats. Though there are many variations to this well-known move, even the simplest form is known for building overall body strength. If you feel like unweighted squats are too easy or not effective enough, you can use home weights such as one-liter water bottles in each hand. Donâ€™t forget to share your progress on social media!

posts.title: Calf raises - The best way to get those calves toned
posts.content: Another way to activate your glutes and strengthen your hamstrings is to do some calf raises. Activating the calves has great benefits and adds to toning the structure of your legs. Different styles of foot positions will help you target different sections of your leg. If you point your toes inwards, you will work the outer sections and vice versa. So get on with it!

posts.title: Plank/Side-plank - Get your core strong by the time this quarantine is over
posts.content: Planks are the perfect exercise to work out your core and strengthen your abdominal muscles. Planks help you focus on muscles at the center of your body core and side planks work on the side and back fat and help tone your body. You can always start with one minute or 30-second plank and then take it up a notch when youâ€™re ready!

posts.title: Crunches - The father of all ab exercises
posts.content: This is the father of all ab exercises. This is the ultimate starter-pack to get your desired six pack. But, remember to do it right because crunches tend to put a lot of pressure on your spinal cord. If youâ€™re finding it difficult, try lifting your legs. This will put some weight on your stomach muscles, making it easier to do the exercise.

posts.title: Dancing- Nothing beats moving to a good tune!
posts.content: Nothing beats moving to a good tune! Just because you do not like to exercise, does not mean you have to be unfit. You can always turn to dancing. If you love to jive, tango, twist or even pop-n-lock, feel free. It is not only a great way to burn those social distancing calories, but it also works wonders to tone your body. So, create a playlist and get moving!

posts.title: Exercise routines by fitness influencers - Your virtual personal instructor
posts.content: The Internet is vast and full of influencers, among those are fitness gurus and trainers who will upload their routines to literally every platform of social media. You can follow their routines - from Zumba to pilates, there are many for each. Think of them as your virtual personal trainer. You can even follow the health plans and diets they offer. All of it for free!

posts.title: Cleaning - Clean and stay fit
posts.content: Again, if you do not want to do these hardcore workouts you can opt for one that has two benefits in one - cleaning. Not only will your house be sparkly and bright - you will also have worked yourself into a toned body and a good night's sleep. Something as simple as scrubbing the floors will help you burn off a good 190 calories.

posts.title: Gardening - Be fit while going green
posts.content: A lot of people dimiss the advantages of gardening but not only does your lawn look pretty but it legit acts as a hardcore workout. Ever tried digging a hole in the ground? Ever tried squatting while weeding? Did you know that you can burn upto 280 calories by mowing your lawn? So, if you have been planning to take up a hobby, you can try gardening.

posts.title: Yoga - For a stronger mind, body and soul
posts.content: Now, if you donâ€™t want anything as intense as the ones mentioned above you can also opt for yoga. Itâ€™s a great way to ease your body and mind into exercise mode, it barely requires any space and will help calm feelings of anxiety. As a beginner, you can check out basic videos on YouTube to learn some easy poses. It will leave you in a state of Zen!

title: Here's What You Need to Know about the Kutcher's Quarantine Wine
desc: It is not often that you hear about quarantine wine to fight COVID-19, but today is an exception. Check out Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunisâ€™s take on this. Yup, you read that right. The That â€˜70s Showâ€™s lead actors and, may we add, one of the hottest Hollywood couples Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunis launched a new quarantine wine. Mila came up with the idea of creating a quarantined-themed wine to help raise proceeds for multiple COVID-19 response efforts. Ashton pitched the idea to the co-founder of Nocking Point, Andrew Harding. After a wine sourcing and wine-tasting, the idea turned into a reality. The Oregon Pinot Noir was then bottled. Hereâ€™s everything else you need to know about the launch.

posts.title: The day Quarantine Wine was born
posts.content:
View this post on Instagram

Mila and I are Launching Quarantine wine! 100% of profits go to covid-19 relief efforts https://officialquarantinewine.com pls share on social media #QuarantineWine #SocialDistancing

A post shared by Ashton Kutcher (@aplusk) on Apr 19, 2020 at 9:38am PDT

On April 19, 2020, Ashton Kutcher made a public announcement on Instagram about the launch of their Quarantine Wine. It said that 100% of the profits would go to COVID-19 response efforts. This makes us love the couple even more.

posts.title: More info on the wine
posts.content:
View this post on Instagram

Mila and I are launching quarantine wine! 100% of profits got to covid-19 relief! @nockingpoint #quarantineWine #socialdistancing

A post shared by Ashton Kutcher (@aplusk) on Apr 19, 2020 at 9:44am PDT

Right after the launch, Ashton and Mila put up a video explaining how the label of the bottle is interactive, letting buyers scribble down who itâ€™s being toasted to. The shout out from Ashton to Mila in this video is adorable, donâ€™t miss it. Here are the charities these profits will go to.

posts.title: GiveDirectly - Provides cash grants to families
posts.content: This nonprofit allows people to make donations to the less fortunate directly in the form of cash grants with SNAP, a program. This will help provide cash relief to people most affected by the pandemic, such as those who have lost their jobs and canâ€™t pay rent, among others.

posts.title: Direct Relief - Provides medical equipment to frontline workers
posts.content: With the cases of coronavirus skyrocketing, medical supplies are scarce, without which itâ€™s difficult for doctors to perform the necessary tests. Direct Relief aims to curb this shortage by providing protective equipment and essential medical equipment to workers through emergency deliveries every day.

posts.title: Frontline Responders Fund - Supplying PPE and ventilators
posts.content: If a health worker is infected with the virus, they are kept in quarantine for at least 14 days. That means one member less to help. Protective gear, however, can help avoid that. This crowd-funding initiative by GoFundMe helps purchase and deliver critical supplies, such as masks, gloves, gowns, and ventilators to medical professionals in the country.

posts.title: Americaâ€™s Food Fund - Provides reliable safe access to food
posts.content: While COVID-19 cases spiked, there were already about 37 million people who were unsure of where their next meal would come from. Thanks to yet another fundraiser by GoFundMe, a collaboration between Feeding America and World Central Kitchen, people now have reliable access to meals.

posts.title: Letâ€™s not forget the wines, shall we?
posts.content: The wine is from a 2018 Pinot Noir from Willamette Valley. For $50, you get yourself two bottles of this masterpiece, and for members of the Nocking Point Wine Club, itâ€™s just $40. The availability of this wine is still top-secret. According to the site, it should ship out early May.

posts.title: Speaking of Willamette Valley, hereâ€™s a bit on the appellation front
posts.content: The wine is made with Willamette Valley pinot noir grapes, and we cannot emphasize enough on how lovely that is! Whatâ€™s certain is that the wine is something to look forward to, especially during this quarantine. Although, you will need to be over 21 if you want to receive this package.

posts.title: A tiny bit on the consulting winemakers - The Kutcher family

title: Hereâ€™s What the Worldâ€™s Leading Health Experts Think Our Pandemic Summer Will Look Like
desc: With no end in sight yet of the global pandemic, the summer of 2020 is going to be unprecedented. Check out what health experts expect in the coming months. The summer of 2020 is bringing in a new normal, with masks, quarantine, social distancing, and temperature checks. We donâ€™t know how long we have to live with novel coronavirus. Dr. Anthony Fauci, the Director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and the voice of this situation, since its inception, has stated that itâ€™s â€œentirely conceivable and possibleâ€ for the virus to rebound in autumn. Hereâ€™s what other public health experts and scientists have to say about lifting lockdowns, consequences of COVID-19, and the pandemic summer weâ€™re going through right now.

posts.title: Caitlin Rivers
posts.content:
A senior scholar at the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security, Caitlin Rivers (@cmyeaton), is an expert in outbreak science, epidemiology, disease modeling, and health security. She is also an Assistant Professor at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.

Iâ€™ve been noticing a dangerous polarization in our discussions around navigating our way through the pandemic. Reopening is said to be playing games with peopleâ€™s lives. Continuing stay at home measures is said to be without regard for the economy. This is a false choice. 1/

— Caitlin Rivers, PhD (@cmyeaton) May 7, 2020

posts.title: Michael Mina
posts.content:
An Assistant Professor of epidemiology at Harvard T. H. Chan School of Public Health, Michael Mina (@michaelmina_lab), is also a core member of the Center for Communicable Disease Dynamics (CCDD). He is a well-known epidemiologist, immunologist, and physician expert in vaccines, infectious diseases, immunity, and public health.

I think too soon is anytime before we have good systems in place for early warning signs to tell us that transmission is taking off. If we don't have the public health warning systems in place, we may be back where we just were, with hospitals, in some areas, drowning.

— Michael Mina (@michaelmina_lab) May 1, 2020

posts.title: Aaron E. Carroll
posts.content:
Aaron E. Carroll (@aaronecarroll), an HSR fellow at IU Medical School, is a pediatrician and author. He writes for the NYT and NYT Opinion and is also one of the editors in chief of the health services research blog The Incidental Economist.

I hate being in lockdown. I think that the economic costs of lockdowns are terrible. I want to get out of lockdown.

That's why I'm consistently advocating for way more testing and the infrastructure to prevent us from needing another future lockdown.

— Aaron E. Carroll (@aaronecarroll) May 14, 2020

posts.title: Andy Slavitt
posts.content:
The ex-head of Obama Care (The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act), Andy Slavitt (@ASlavitt), is not only the founder of the United States of Care and Town Hall Ventures but also hosts the podcast In the Bubble.

May is like a massive trial on what things work and what doesnâ€™t. We will be surprised to the good end to the bad. And hopefully we are smart enough to learn our lessons. 29/

— Andy Slavitt @ ???? (@ASlavitt) May 16, 2020

posts.title: Scott Gottlieb
posts.content:
A resident fellow at The American Enterprise Institute, Scott Gottlieb (@ScottGottliebMD), was the 23rd Commissioner of the US FDA. He's a member of the Board of Directors of healthcare tech and pharma companies, including Pfizer, Aetion, Tempus, and Illumina.

THREAD: Nationwide we're continuing to see hospitalizations and deaths fall, both total national data and states outside of hard hit New York tristate region. There are however some states that are experiencing increase cases, hospitalizations, deaths that bear close watching 1/x pic.twitter.com/kveKbHGgG7

— Scott Gottlieb, MD (@ScottGottliebMD) May 17, 2020

posts.title: Trevor Bedford
posts.content:
A member of the Vaccine and Infectious Diseases Division and the Computational Biology Program of the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, scientist Trevor Bedford (@trvrb), has expertise in viruses, immunity, and evolution. Additionally, he is an Affiliate Associate Professor of Genome Sciences and Epidemiology at the University of Washington.

I know all the discussion is about a possible "2nd wave", but I've found this odd given that we haven't finished the first one. I would think quite possible that, nationally, we're in for a scenario of a long plateau. 1/10

— Trevor Bedford (@trvrb) April 30, 2020

posts.title: Tom Inglesby
posts.content:
Director of the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security, Tom Inglesby (@T_Inglesby), is one of the renowned names in public health preparedness, pandemics, infectious diseases, and biosecurity. He is a Professor in the Department of Environmental Health and Engineering at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.

Comments on recent #COVID19 US developments, some positive, some not: US still in plateau w/ daily 25-30,000 cases and average of ~2000 daily deaths for ~5 wks. For perspective, the average number of US deaths on a given day is ~ 7,700. https://t.co/ZC5zMjpddF 1/x

— Tom Inglesby (@T_Inglesby) May 10, 2020

posts.title: Dr. Tara C. Smith
posts.content:
An infectious-disease epidemiologist and a writer, Dr. Tara C. Smith (@aetiology), leads research in the Smith Emerging Infections Laboratory at Kent State University. You can know more about her research and work at taracsmith.com.

I'm worried about a spike. Not a 2nd wave as we're not done with the 1st, but an increase around the state. Maybe our hospitals can handle it. Perhaps we've increased capacity & slowed spread to where we'll be OK. But that's still a lot of deaths & the wrong message to send. /fin

— Dr. Tara C. Smith (@aetiology) May 4, 2020

posts.title: Florian Krammer
posts.content:
A Professor at the Department of Microbiology at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, Florian Krammer (@florian_krammer), is an expert in applied virology and biotechnology. In fact, he started The Krammer Laboratory at Icahn.

The situation is definitely getting better in New York. But there are some countries that don't seem to do so well. Russia, Mexico, Brazil, Saudi Arabia, Peru etc. are all on their way up. And then there are many countries that don't really test. I am very worried about this.

— Florian Krammer (@florian_krammer) May 2, 2020

posts.title: Abraar Karan
posts.content:
A doctor at the Brigham and Women's Hospital and Harvard Medical School, Abraar Karan (@AbraarKaran), is a leading expert figure in epidemic response and emerging infectious diseases. He is now working at the Massachusetts Department of Public Health on state-level COVID19 response.

As a country, we have a long way to go before point 2 is perfect. But it needs to be good enough before we talk seriously about re-opening.

This is the simple answer to those confused about why a slow in new cases is not enough of a reason to re-open.

— Abraar Karan (@AbraarKaran) May 15, 2020

posts.title: Dr. Muge Cevik
posts.content:
A researcher and clinician-scientist at the School of Medicine at the University of St.Andrews in Scotland, Dr. Muge Cevik (@mugecevik) has expertise in infectious diseases and virology. In fact, she has been advising the Chief Medical Officer of Scotland and WHO on COVID-19.

Conclusion 2: (a) we need to redesign our living/working spaces & rethink how to provide better, ventilated living/working environment for those who live in deprived & cramped areas; (b) avoid close, sustained contact indoors & in public transport, & maintain personal hygiene.

— Dr Muge Cevik (@mugecevik) May 4, 2020

posts.title: Dr. Tom Frieden
posts.content:
The President of the global health initiative "Resolve to Save Lives," Dr. Tom Frieden (@DrTomFrieden), is a leading expert figure in tobacco control, tuberculosis, health administration and policy. He has also been the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and the Commissioner of the NYC Health Dept.

We have to be prepared for changes like this in our new normal. Thread on one person's experience traveling from Paris to Hong Kong. https://t.co/AC4Tv5zVSw

— Dr. Tom Frieden (@DrTomFrieden) May 18, 2020

posts.title: David Juurlink
posts.content:
A well-known name in the field of clinical pharmacology and toxicology, David Juurlink (@DavidJuurlink) is the head of the Division of Clinical Pharmacology & Toxicology at Sunnybrook Health Sciences Center. Apart from this, heâ€™s a drug safety researcher from the University of Toronto Faculty of Medicine.

This thread and the embedded one by @KeithNHumphreys paint a grim picture of how cultural forces are likely to significantly worsen the toll of coronavirus in the United States https://t.co/m10WsW3ON7

— David Juurlink (@DavidJuurlink) May 13, 2020

posts.title: Dr. Robert R. Redfield
posts.content:
The present Director of the Centers for Disease Control & Prevention, Dr. Robert R. Redfield (@CDCDirector), is not only one of the biggest names in virology but also the administrator of the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry.

CDC tracks 12 different forecasting models of possible #COVID19 deaths in the US. As of May 11, all forecast an increase in deaths in the coming weeks and a cumulative total exceeding 100,000 by June 1. See national & state forecasts: https://t.co/PI1AtLCCmt pic.twitter.com/iylBnom5U0

— Dr. Robert R. Redfield (@CDCDirector) May 15, 2020

posts.title: Devi Sridhar
posts.content:
A Professor and the Chair of Global Public Health at the University of Edinburgh Medical School, Devi Sridhar(@devisridhar) is an expert in the governance of health systems, including health policies, health financing, and health security. She is also the Director of the Global Health Governance Program.

All signs point to this virus hitting particularly hard next Winter as flu season starts, activity moves largely indoors & people tire of distancing. Must use the summer & next few months to prepare public health infrastructure & get systems in place bc winter is coming.

— Devi Sridhar (@devisridhar) May 17, 2020
